ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my writing, listening, speaking and reading abilities in Chinese. I feel like I can actually have a simple conversation with a native speaker!
Learning how to read, write, and speak Mandarin
This class greatly increased my ability to both speak and read standard mandarin. I now feel comfortable with basic conversations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Personally, I found this course to be quite difficult given the online format and pace of content. However, given its difficulty and workload, I did learn quite a bit of Chinese.

The strength is definitely the professors. They are so caring and knowledgeable, they are the best at what they do. Even online, they were able to create a sense of community and a very enjoyable learning environment. They make you always feel comfortable, even when you don't really know how to express something. There's no weaknesses! The Chinese department is just amazing.
It wasn't always as interactive as it could be. I think incorporating things like skits would help the learning process exponentially.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like this course was taught very well online. I just feel like for the pronunciation it was difficult to get some of the details.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Similar to L1 this class is fast-paced with a heavy workload. I would not recommend this class to anyone casually interested in learning Chinese. If you take this class, be prepared for a large time commitment and the difficulty of this course.

Please, if you have a minimum interest in taking Chinese (and if you're reading this it means you do), just take it! It will be a lot of work, but it will also be a lot of fun. It's so rewarding, by the end of the semester you will feel how much you have improved. The professors are AMAZING, I'm sure you won't regret taking it. If it was this good being online, I can't even imagine how it will be in person!
Yes, but only if you are willing to go further with the language.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: When a student couldn't attend, the session was recorded.
